briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. Welcome to the climate briefing for December 28, 2025. The climate-related news gathered today highlights various domestic and international efforts towards carbon neutrality, even amidst a global sense of crisis.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Intensifying Climate Crisis Warnings and Their Ripple Effects
sections.content: The world continues to receive urgent warnings about the intensifying climate crisis. In particular, the warning that global warming will accelerate if 2.7 billion people do not reduce beef consumption once again reminds us of the serious impact our dietary habits have on climate change [2, 6]. Scientists strongly assert that disaster could be imminent if leaders do not heed these warnings [28], and indeed, concerns have been raised that climate policies have been sidelined amidst intensifying extreme weather in 2025 [31]. Climate change has not only emerged as a major public health issue [34] but is also causing economic instability, acting as a risk factor in the foreign exchange USDJPY market [32]. Even biodiversity-rich areas like the Sundarbans and remote regions of Antarctica are facing the threat of climate change [29, 33].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Diverse Efforts to Achieve Domestic Carbon Neutrality Goals
sections.content: Domestically, diverse efforts are actively underway to achieve the 2050 carbon neutrality goal. The Ministry of Climate is recruiting promising startups and eco-startups to lead carbon neutrality, encouraging innovation with support of up to 200 million KRW [7, 11, 16, 19]. Local governments are also actively participating: Yuseong-gu is expanding its certification for excellent carbon footprint apartments, promoting carbon neutrality in daily life [8, 10]; Gwangmyeong-si announced achievements in jobs for new middle-aged, youth, and carbon neutrality [12, 18]; and Gimhae-si is encouraging community-wide action by selecting top carbon neutrality practice organizations [14]. Furthermore, Gwangju-si signed an agreement with the Korea Wood Culture Promotion Institute for the operation of a carbon-neutral wood education comprehensive center [9, 13], and Geochang-gun is laying the groundwork for a future-oriented eco-city to lead 2050 carbon neutrality [15], accelerating the transition to a carbon-neutral society through public-private cooperation [17]. In the corporate sector, voluntary participation across industries is notable, with HD Hyundai Construction Equipment and HD Hyundai Infracore achieving the highest CDP climate change response ratings [3], and SK PIC Global accelerating towards net-zero by 2040 through process innovation [20].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± The Importance of Energy Transition and Renewable Energy Expansion
sections.content: Discussions and actions regarding energy transition and renewable energy expansion, essential in the era of climate change, are ongoing. Recently, the book 'Energy Transition in the Era of Climate Change' was introduced, once again highlighting the importance of this topic [1]. Internationally, China is projected to gain an advantage in eco-friendly fuel production by establishing a 'virtuous cycle' structure through its renewable energy support policies [21]. Domestically, concrete efforts to expand renewable energy infrastructure are underway, with Mungyeong-si securing 880 million KRW in national funding for the 2026 new and renewable energy convergence support project [22]. Political circles have also emphasized consistent promotion of renewable energy development policies, suggesting that stable policy support is key to a successful energy transition [23].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Challenges of Global Climate Action and International Cooperation
sections.content: Global climate action continues to face various challenges, emphasizing the importance of international cooperation to address them. It has been pointed out that to expand urban climate action, it is necessary to bridge the research gap between the Global North and South and implement interventions tailored to local contexts [25]. Meanwhile, interesting research findings have been published indicating that the level of religiosity influences actions regarding the climate crisis [26], prompting the exploration of new approaches to motivate climate action. Internationally, the 1st International Conference on Climate Change Impacts is scheduled to be held in Semnan [27], and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) is also continuing its efforts to combat climate change [30]. Domestically, the government will implement an emissions trading system by allocating greenhouse gas emission allowances to companies for five years starting next year. However, despite increasing the 'paid allowance ratio,' concerns about the transparency of its reduction effects have been raised [24], indicating a need to enhance policy effectiveness. Additionally, efforts to strengthen disaster management capabilities through improving disaster prevention performance target standards in preparation for climate change [5] and climate change adaptation efforts such as supporting beekeeping farms in Seogwipo [4] are ongoing.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has shown that despite intensifying warnings of a climate crisis, concrete efforts towards carbon neutrality and renewable energy transition are continuing both domestically and internationally. For these efforts to lead to meaningful outcomes, policy consistency and international cooperation must be further strengthened. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: 2.36 Billion Tons of Carbon Emission Allowances Allocated to Companies Over 5 Years; 'Paid Purchase Ratio' Increased, But Reduction Effect Uncertain
articles.original_title: 5ë…„ê°„ íƒ„ì†Œë°°ì¶œê¶Œ 23.6ì–µt ê¸°ì—…ì— í• ë‹¹Â·Â·Â·â€˜ëˆ ë‚´ê³  ì‚¬ëŠ” ë¹„ìœ¨â€™ ëŠ˜ë ¸ì§€ë§Œ ê°ì¶• íš¨ê³¼ ë¶ˆíˆ¬ëª…
articles.description: Minister of Climate, Energy, and Environment Kim Sung-hwan briefed on the 2035 National Greenhouse Gas Reduction Target (NDC) and the 4th planning period's emission allowance allocation plan at the Government Complex Seoul briefing room on the 10th. Reporter Jung Hyo-jin reports that the government will allocate 2.36299 billion tons of greenhouse gas emission allowances to 772 companies for use over the next five years, starting next year. With the commencement of the fourth planning period for the emissions trading system, the carbon emission standards that companies must bear...

summary.phenomenon: The South Korean government will allocate 2.36299 billion tons of greenhouse gas emission allowances to 772 companies over the next five years, starting next year, marking the commencement of the fourth planning period for the emissions trading system.
summary.cause: This measure is in accordance with the government's 2035 National Greenhouse Gas Reduction Target (NDC) and the 4th planning period's emission allowance allocation plan.
summary.outlook: Despite an increase in the proportion of emission allowances that companies must purchase, the actual greenhouse gas reduction effect is assessed as uncertain.
